document_title: Primary essential hypertension: Causes, symptoms, treatment
subsection_content:
To diagnose essential hypertension, your doctor will first check your blood pressure with a blood pressure monitor. If the reading is too high, your doctor may recommend that you check your blood pressure at home at certain intervals. You will be instructed on how to use the blood pressure monitor to get accurate results. The final index is determined by the average value of blood pressure measurements at different times.
You will be asked to self-monitor your blood pressure at home if you have signs of high blood pressure
In addition, your doctor will conduct a physical examination to check for signs of cardiovascular disease. At your visit, your doctor will check your eyes, listen to your heart, lungs, and blood flow in your neck. Small blood vessels under the eyes can be a sign of damage from high blood pressure, as can blood vessels elsewhere.
Finally, your doctor may ask you to do the following laboratory tests to check your heart and kidneys:
Blood tests check cholesterol levels;; Echocardiography;; Electrocardiogram (EKG or ECG);; Blood tests, urine tests, or ultrasound to check kidney and other organ function.
